repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Close #30504

Early draft. Callback doesn't have arguments yet.

comment_data.body:
Normally callbacks should be `on_xx`, but if `on_mouse` is too awkward here, we can just call it `mouse`.
```suggestion
///   - mouse: Specify how this window affects mouse events. Defaults to `focusable` value.
```

Somewhat off-topic but: RPC clients could easily implement their own "callbacks" if our API "callback" fields had a string form invoked as Lua which received a channel-id. 

Example RPC call:

    nvim_open_win(... { mouse = 'local ev = ...; vim.rpcrequest(ev.chan, "my_method")' })
the "If this field..." should go near the top
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3196,6 +3196,16 @@ nvim_open_win({buffer}, {enter}, {config})                   *nvim_open_win()*
                   • focusable: Enable focus by user actions (wincmds, mouse
                     events). Defaults to true. Non-focusable windows can be
                     entered by |nvim_set_current_win()|.
+                  • mouse: Specify how this window affects mouse events. May
+                    be a boolean or a Lua callback.
+                    • If false, mouse events ignore this window.
+                    • If true, mouse events interact with this window
+                      normally.
+                    • If a Lua callback, mouse events interact with this
+                      window, but the callback is called in place of the
+                      default handling. If this field is not specified but
+                      `focusable` is specified, the value of `focusable` will
+                      be used.

comment_data.body:
Wonder if this should be something like
```
grid->mouse != kWinMouseIgnore
```
`WinMouseEvent` is only used in `w_config`. In `ScreenGrid` a simple boolean is used. I've renamed that to `mouse_enabled` to avoid confusion.

It may be hard to describe the default value here:
- When `mouse` was `true` or `false`, and only `focusable` is specified in `nvim_win_set_config`, `mouse` needs to be set to the same value as `focusable` for backward-compatibility.
- However, when `mouse` was a callback, it's better not to change it when only `focusable` is specified in `nvim_win_set_config`.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3196,6 +3196,15 @@ nvim_open_win({buffer}, {enter}, {config})                   *nvim_open_win()*
                   • focusable: Enable focus by user actions (wincmds, mouse
                     events). Defaults to true. Non-focusable windows can be
                     entered by |nvim_set_current_win()|.
+                  • mouse: Specify how this window affects mouse events. May
+                    be a boolean or a Lua callback. Defaults to `focusable`
+                    value.

comment_data.body:
I was originally thinking that it would be good to track if `mouse` had ever been manually set, and if it had been then don't automatically change it to follow `focusable`. But doing as you describe is nice and simple.

It means that if you ever manually set `mouse` to something different than `focusable`, it is probably best to always set it when setting `focusable`. That's reasonable and simple.

I guess it's friendly to not automatically change `mouse` when it's a callback; but it doesn't seem to offer that much and makes things more difficult to describe. Instead of special casing callback, in `nvim_win_set_config` could just say something like:
"If `focusable` is specified and `mouse` is not, then `mouse` is set to the same value as `focusable`."
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3196,6 +3196,15 @@ nvim_open_win({buffer}, {enter}, {config})                   *nvim_open_win()*
                   • focusable: Enable focus by user actions (wincmds, mouse
                     events). Defaults to true. Non-focusable windows can be
                     entered by |nvim_set_current_win()|.
+                  • mouse: Specify how this window affects mouse events. May
+                    be a boolean or a Lua callback. Defaults to `focusable`
+                    value.

comment_regular_data.body:
Tried a variety of cases, looks like 
```
vim.api.nvim_win_get_config(wid).mouse
```
is alway `nil`.

Wanted to look at how `mouse` changed when `focusable` is changed given different starting conditions.

The callback is now invoked for floating windows, although it doesn't have arguments yet (but `getmousepos()` and `getcharmod()` should work).

It isn't hard to enable the callback for non-floating windows, but maybe that should be addressed together with #29365.

> The callback is now invoked for floating windows, although it doesn't have arguments yet

Looking at the output of `getmousepos()` can guess at the argument :) Mouse press event, mouse release event. Drag event if holding the mouse down and move across floating window. No mouse events if sweep across floater until `set mousemoveevent`.

Implementing window dragging will have problems. If click on left border, then move left, there is no event, drag or otherwise. Could leave an empty cell outside the border and don't move too fast (width not compatible). Something to consider later. (some systems might keep delivering drag event even after the window is left, and there's exit window events)

> (but `getmousepos()` 

Yes, been working for a few pushes

> and `getcharmod()` should work).

Ah, so that's how you get that info. Cool. Yes, that works. Too bad the state of the buttons is not available. Kind of like for `nvim_input_mouse`'s `{button}` but a bit mask.
 
> It isn't hard to enable the callback for non-floating windows, but maybe that should be addressed together with #29365.

Popups don't need this AFAIK. 

Interestingly, in simple cases it could be part of a workaround for not getting drag events past the edge or window leave events. Would require temporarily, while dragging a window, swapping into the popup's surrounding window a helper `mouse` function to track movement out of the popup. But in general much more complicated because of overlapping windows.

Maybe a "global" mouse function?

title: feat(float): more configurable mouse event handling
